awd_titl_txt: SBE: Small: THE NEW SECURITY CALCULUS: Incentivizing Good User Security Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
The threat and impact of cybersecurity breaches are felt throughout society with massive financial losses to businesses and breach of national secrets. Human behavior is increasing seen as a fundamental security vulnerability that is at the center of many security breaches. Several approaches have been used for improving user security behavior, including enacting information security policies, providing security awareness training, and introducing penalties for security violations; these approaches have not been very effective. In this research, we are influencing human security decision analysis through direct financial incentives and behavioral interventions such that the decision analysis aligns with economic rationality. 

The dominant theoretical frameworks used by researchers to improve information security are Protection Motivation Theory and Deterrence Theory. These theories suggest that users make rational security decisions by cognitively weighing the relative gains and losses associated with their choices within a decision calculus. They assume that users will respond rationally to perceived security threats in the environment and to sanctions imposed on noncompliance. Users are expected to internally regulate their behavior based on an understanding of security threats and the consequences of risky behavior; however, in the course of daily activities users often minimize the risks associated with their behavior and may rationalize noncompliant behavior by perceiving that costs of compliance outweigh benefits. We seek to improve security compliance by changing the user?s security decision calculus. Drawing on principles of behavioral economics, we use extrinsic rewards (i.e. financial incentives) to initiate compliance, and psychological manipulations (nudges) to promote ongoing internal regulation of security behavior, such that users sustain secure behaviors when external incentives are no longer in place. The multidisciplinary nature of this work enhances understanding of many information security issues and provides a fresh perspective for research on behavioral security and security economics.

Security Incentives for Improving Security Behavior

 

Abstract

Our research examines the role of financial incentives in improving user security behavior in organizations. Through three coordinated studies, it shows that incentives can positively influence user security behavior. While the role of extrinsic motivation is short-lived, our results also show that the behavior can be maintained through the use of nudges and reminders.

 

Background and Findings

The motivation of employees to comply with security policies and adopt good security hygiene is a key imperative for improving information security in organizations. Motivation comes from within whether it is extrinsic in terms of rewards or enhancement of self-image or intrinsic where we engage in activities for no reward other than for the pure joy of engaging in these activities (James, 1890). Information security compliance is not an inherently joyful task that will engender intrinsic motivation. Rather, it is a tedious never-ending task that reduces productivity, adds to cognitive load, and interferes with day-to-day tasks; consequently, extrinsic incentives are necessary to motivate employees to engage in security policy compliance; extrinsic incentives can be positive (or rewarding) or negative (or punitive). Punitive incentives have been considered for security compliance and have been well researched and instituted in organizations, albeit with limited success. There are several reasons why these measures are not effective: first, behavior changes that result from extrinsic motivation (for both positive and negative measures) are typically temporary and are likely to last only until punitive measures are withdrawn (Skinner, 1971); second, punishment alone does not offer information about more desired behaviors (Lukowiak and Bridges, 2010); and third, punitive measures can lead to employee negative behaviors (Skinner, 1971). There is a lack of research on the use of positive incentives to motivate compliance with security policies. Drawing on principles of behavioral economics, we test the use of extrinsic positive rewards (i.e., financial incentives) to initiate compliance, and psychological nudges to promote ongoing internal regulation of security behavior.

We study the effect of financial incentives as the motivator to initiate desired security behaviors and the effect of nudges as the measures to help retain the behaviors. Motivation can range in a spectrum from intrinsic to extrinsic. Since security is not inherently an intrinsically motivating task for most individuals, extrinsic motivators are required for changing user security behavior. While the threat, punishments, and sanctions, have been investigated extensively for fostering desirable security behavior, there are negative connotations of such behavior in eliciting negative user behaviors such as isolation, anger, low morale, and deception.  Our studies have shown that positive (financial) incentives can be workable extrinsic motivators without the negative connotations of the negative extrinsic (threats, sanctions, and punishments) motivators.

Our studies (Goel et al., 2021) have an implication for theories in showing that financial incentives are effective in motivating users toward desired information security behaviors. With the lack of intrinsic motivation due to the nature of information security tasks and the lack of immediate results, it is difficult for people to correctly evaluate the value of performing these tasks and to make correct decisions when needed. Providing financial incentives made the value of compliance with the information security policies explicit and supports people’s mental calculus when deciding whether or not to perform the tasks. It not only attached an explicit value to information security behaviors but made it more relevant to an individual as well. Furthermore, our study showed that the effects brought by financial incentives retained for some time even after the incentives were removed, and that the effects were boosted if other supportive methods kick in. While both negative and positive extrinsic motivators have the limitation of losing their effectiveness after incentives are removed, our research shows the that use of nudges can overcome this limitation and prolong the maintenance of the desired behavior.

Practically, our study results provided an easily applicable method to initiate the desired information security practice in employees. Compared to the enormous cost of security breaches, improving the security practices with financial incentives will be cost-effective for the organizations. Companies are spending millions of dollars on organization information security, investing a small fraction of these investments for incentivizing users to engage in cybersecurity will improve their ROI on security investments.

 

References

[1]    Goel, S., Williams, K. J., Huang, J., & Warkentin, M. (2021). Can financial incentives help with the struggle for security policy compliance?. Information & management, 58(4), 103447.

[2]    James, W. (2005). The Principles of Psychology (New York: Henry Holt and Company, 1890). Istanbul Üniversitesi İlahiyat Fakültesi Dergisi Sayı: 12, Yıl.

[3]    Lukowiak, T., & Bridges, J. (2010). Punishment Strategies: First Choice or Last Resort. Journal of the American Academy of Special Education Professionals, 63, 72.

[4]    Skinner, B. F. (1971). Operant conditioning. The encyclopedia of education, 7, 29-33.
